Univ Studies 3: Algorithms to Live By -- Spring 2017

  • Introduction. Human activities are constrained by limited space and time, which gives rise to various decisions and problems that we must face as we go through life. What should we do, or leave undone, in a day or a lifetime? How much messiness should we accept? What balance of new activities and familiar favorites is most fulfilling? Although these are clearly questions that humans face, they are strongly related to constraints faced by computers, and computer scientists have been grappling with their version of such issues for decades. The solutions they've found have much to teach us.
  • Course Overview. This seminar explores how computer algorithms and algorithmic thinking can untangle some very human questions. It will explore how to have better hunches and when to leave things to chance, how to deal with overwhelming choices, and how best to connect with others. From finding a job to finding a parking spot, from organizing one's inbox to understanding the workings of memory, this seminar is directed at bringing the wisdom of computer science into strategies for human living.
  • Class meetings
    • Lectures: Friday 11-11:50am in Donald Bren Hall 1425
  • Instructor
    • Professor Michael Goodrich -- goodrich (at) uci.edu
  • Class Requirements
    • Grades will be determined 50% from weekly quizes based on the readings and 50% from attendance and class participation. Each student may miss one class meeting during the quarter without penalty.

  • Laptop policy. Open laptop computers are not allowed during class meetings. Here's why.

  • Text. The course textbook is Algorithms to Live By: The Computer Science of Human Decisions, by Brian Christian and Tom Griffiths.

Tentative Schedule

  • Week 1: Optimal stopping: When to stop looking. Intro. and Chap. 1
  • Week 2: The multi-armed bandit problem. Finding the latest or greatest. Chap. 2
  • Week 3: Sorting. Finding order and searching. Chap. 3
  • Week 4: Caching your memory. Chap. 4 (Sleator-Tarjan paper on the move-to-front heuristic)
  • Week 5: Scheduling your life. Chap. 5
  • Week 6: Bayes Rule. Laplace's Rule of succession. Predicting the future. Chaps. 6-7
  • Week 7: Greedy Algorithms. Relaxation. Chap. 8
  • Week 8: Dealing with and exploiting randomness. Chap. 9
  • Week 9: Networking and connections. Social Networks slides (PDF). Chap. 10
    For fun: Mathematical collaboration distance tool, The Oracle of Bacon.
  • Week 10: Game theory. Chap. 11 and Conclusion
